metadata.title: Cirrus SR22
aws::graph::propositions: # Cirrus SR22 Safety Statistics and CAPS Deployments
By the end of 2013, the Cirrus SR22 fatality rate had been reduced to 1.01 per 100,000 flight hours.
The reduction in Cirrus SR22 fatality rate was attributed to better training.
The reduction in Cirrus SR22 fatality rate was particularly attributed to better training in the use of the ballistic parachute system.
The Cirrus SR22 fatality rate continued to decrease in 2014.
The Cirrus SR22 fatality rate decreased to .42 per 100,000 flight hours in 2014.
The .42 per 100,000 flight hours fatality rate was one of the aviation industry's lowest.
2014 marked the fewest fatalities in a single year for Cirrus since 2001.
2014 was the first year where the number of CAPS deployments exceeded the number of fatal accidents.
In 2014, there were 12 CAPS deployments.
In 2014, there were 3 fatal accidents involving Cirrus aircraft.
CAPS stands for Cirrus Airframe Parachute System.
As of September 2018, pilots had deployed the SR-series parachute 79 times.
As of September 2018, there were 163 survivors from SR-series parachute deployments.
A CAPS deployment failed in March 2021.
After the failed CAPS deployment in March 2021, Cirrus issued a service bulletin.
Cirrus replaced the firing mechanism in the CAP systems after March 2021.
The firing mechanism controls the primer material that ignites the chute's rocket.
Cirrus replaced the firing mechanism for 347 Cirrus SR aircraft.
Cirrus replaced the firing mechanism for 26 SF50 Vision jets.

text:
By the end of 2013, the fatality rate had been reduced to 1.01 per 100,000 flight hours. This was attributed to better training, particularly in the use of the ballistic parachute system.
The fatality rate continued to decrease in 2014, to .42 per 100,000 flight hours, one of the industry's lowest. This marked the fewest fatalities in a single year for Cirrus since 2001, and the first year where the number of CAPS deployments (12) exceeded the number of fatal accidents (3).
As of September 2018, pilots had deployed the SR-series parachute 79 times, with 163 survivors.
After a failed CAPS deployment in March 2021, Cirrus issued a service bulletin and replaced the firing mechanism in the CAP systems (which control the primer material that ignites the chutes rocket) for 347 Cirrus SR aircraft and 26 SF50 Vision jets.
